oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Audiences; Concerts; Events; Music; Singers; Clothing & dress; Guitars; Stages (Platforms); Stage props; Pews; Auditoriums; Concert halls; Historic buildings; Tabernacles (Buildings)
Acuff, Roy; Smoky Mountain Boys; Ryman Auditorium (Nashville, Tenn.); Grand ole opry (Radio program); Country music; Country gospel music; Music-halls
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Photo taken from the audience level of a performance at the Ryman by Roy Acuff and his Smoky Mountain Boys. Audience, stage, backstage, electronics, and advertisements are all in view.
oai_dc:dc.dc:source: Tennessee Department of Conservation Photograph Collection, 1937-1976
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: After broadcasting from a number of locations, the Grand Ole Opry moved to its 31-year home at the Ryman Auditorium on June 5, 1943. Roy Acuff's country music career took off in the 1930s as he sang and fiddled with his group, the Smoky Mountain Boys. Acuff joined the Opry in 1938. The month of September 1969 found him entertaining the troops in Vietnam, opening the first in his chain of Roy Acuff Cannonball Kitchen restaurants in Nashville, and performing at the Grand Ole Opry.
